page.title: 01Troutbeck and Garburn Pass
page.content: Troutbeck is an attractive long linear village built along a line of wells. It is devited principally to sheep and cattle forming and consists of about 60 houses 8 of which offer bed and breakfast accommodation. One is divided into self-contained holiday flats and there are two hotels : The marked Man and The Queens Head. Otherwise the village is inhabited to a notieable extent by retired people. The village is the principal feature of this area but in the valley bottom there is a large camp site. The Troutbeck valley consists largely of hay and grazing meadows together with mixed scattered woodlands. The Garburn Pass rises along the Eastern slopes of the valley and links Troutbeck with Kentmere. The Eastern slopes are bare and rocky. There are two resevoirs to the south and Capple Howe 1429' is the
